XII Quantum mechanics in three dimensions

XII.1 Coordinates and wavefunction

Three-dimensional space ğ«=xâ¢ğ¢+yâ¢ğ£+zâ¢ğ¤ is spanned by three basis vectors ğ¢, ğ£, ğ¤ with coordinates x, y and z.

The state of a system is described by a wavefunction Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)=Ïˆâ¢(x,y,z).

XII.2 Position operators

The coordinates are associated with three position operators x^, y^, z^ which act as

x^â¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)=xâ¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«),y^â¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)=yâ¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«),z^â¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)=zâ¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«). (184)

These coordinates commute since (x^â¢y^-y^â¢x^)â¢Ïˆâ¢(x,y,z)=xâ¢yâ¢Ïˆâ¢(x,y,z)-yâ¢xâ¢Ïˆâ¢(x,y,z)=0 etc. Hence [x^,y^]=0, [x^,z^]=0, [y^,z^]=0. Therefore, x, y and z are simultaneous observables (they can be measured simultaneously without affecting each other). Indeed, Heisenbergâ€™s uncertainty relation gives, e.g., Î”â¢xâ¢Î”â¢yâ‰¥0, so that it is possible to determine both x and y with no uncertainty, Î”â¢x=Î”â¢y=0.

XII.3 Momentum operators

Momentum ğ©=pxâ¢ğ¢+pyâ¢ğ£+pzâ¢ğ¤ is associated with momentum operators

p^x=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚âˆ‚â¡x,p^y=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚âˆ‚â¡y,p^z=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚âˆ‚â¡z, (185)

which act as

p^xâ¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚â¡Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)âˆ‚â¡x, (186)
p^yâ¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚â¡Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)âˆ‚â¡y, (187)
p^zâ¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚â¡Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)âˆ‚â¡z. (188)

The momentum operators commute with each other because the order of differentiation does not matter for any function Ïˆâ¢(ğ«):

âˆ‚2â¡Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)âˆ‚â¡xâ¢âˆ‚â¡y=âˆ‚2â¡Ïˆâ¢(ğ«)âˆ‚â¡yâ¢âˆ‚â¡x. (189)

Hence [p^x,p^y]=0, [p^x,p^z]=0, [p^y,p^z]=0.

XII.4 Commutators between position and momentum

From one dimension we already know [x^,p^x]=iâ¢â„. This also translates to the commutators [y^,p^y]=iâ¢â„, [z^,p^z]=iâ¢â„.

However, the following commutators vanish: [x^,p^y]=0, [x^,p^z]=0, [y^,p^x]=0, [y^,p^z]=0, [z^,p^x]=0, [z^,p^y]=0.
